awd_titl_txt: Cascadia Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) are a well-documented high-impact practice that has the potential to increase the retention and transfer of underrepresented students in STEM. CUREs have been defined in many ways, but are in essence, used to teach students research skills within the context of regular coursework. Many STEM faculty members within Washington State’s 34 community and technical colleges are developing and implementing CUREs that are matched to the disciplinary fields and curriculum of associated courses. All 34 of these colleges are also adopting the Guided Pathways model to increase students’ retention and successful transfer to four-year universities or direct entry into the workforce. Despite these measures, none of the colleges have institutional plans to implement and sustain CUREs on a broad scale. The goal of the Cascadia CURE Conference (C3) is to convene teams of STEM administrators and faculty from ten Washington State community colleges to create long-term plans to institutionalize the widespread practice of CUREs in a manner tailored to their colleges’ assets, employees, students, and cultures and also consistent with their applications of the Guided Pathways model.  These plans are expected to be aligned with their institution-wide strategic plans. Nationally recognized experts will participate as facilitators and presenters. This will ensure that the colleges’ long-term plans build on prior research concerning the institutionalization of CUREs, and that each plan is achievable using the resources available at each college.

The conference will be facilitated by leaders of the Community College Undergraduate Research Initiative (CCURI), an effort that has to date worked with 142 colleges to develop and institutionalize CUREs. CCURI’s research has identified seven characteristics associated with colleges that have successfully embedded CUREs within their STEM academic cultures. Prior to the conference, each college will complete a baseline survey to assess the academic culture of CUREs on their campus. At the conference, each team will 1) evaluate their college’s capacity for institutionalization of CUREs, based on CCURI’s list of characteristics and other research findings; and 2) write long-term plans for institutionalizing CUREs at scale, using the seven characteristics identified by CCURI. The colleges will repeat the survey after a year to evaluate their progress, as well as note lessons learned that may be useful for other colleges seeking to expand the use of CUREs. This study will help to clarify the applicability of CCURI’s research as a planning and decision-making tool.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Students who participate in undergraduate research experiences (UREs) improve their academic performance and professional skills, and more strongly identify with and persist in STEM disciplines. UREs have been shown to especially benefit those who are historically underrepresented in the STEM workforce.

Course based Undergraduate Research (or CUREs) are a practical way to give students undergraduate research experience at community and technical colleges (CTCs) where faculty are expected to devote most of their time to classroom instruction.

The Cascadia CURE Conference (C3) was a conference held in Leavenworth in Washington state. The goal of the conference was to help each of nine participating CTC teams in WA state system formulate a 10-year strategic plan to expand and sustain CUREs within their college’s academic culture. Each CTC was represented by three faculty members (mostly STEM) and one administrator. Prior to the conference, each team completed an institutional climate survey developed by the Community College Research Initiative (CCURI). The results of the survey were analyzed by PI Solomonson and presented at the conference. The results of the survey indicated that while some of the colleges had established a few CURE courses, no college had a plan to make undergraduate research a part of their culture.

Research done by CCURI (NSF DUE #1524353) has identified three broad categories or tiers of institutionalization, along a spectrum of “no research” to “research as the norm.”

Based on the CCURI research, CTCs in the top-tier category share these seven characteristics:

  1. Undergraduate research (UR) is aligned with institutional priorities (strategic plan, mission, vision, and system-wide initiatives).
  2. UR activities are connected to internal and external (local, regional, and national) networks.
  3. UR is embedded within course instruction (i.e., CUREs).
  4. UR is supported through faculty professional development plans and opportunities.
  5. UR is multi-departmental/interdisciplinary.
  6. UR is implemented in accordance with a shared vision and strategic plan.
  7. UR activities are scaffolded, and not limited to an isolated course within each program of study.

The strategic plans created by each participating CTC at the Cascadia CURE Conference was informed by this research and shared a common end state defined by the above seven characteristics. Developing the plans in this manner was a test of how well CCURI’s research could be used to facilitate institution-level planning by CTCs. A reflection survey at the end of the year was used to learn the progress made and the barriers faced by colleges in creating and implementing the strategic plan.

Conference Details

During the conference, participants were provided with templates developed by CCURI. Jim Hewlett (executive director of CCURI) led the participants through the steps needed to create a strategic plan. These sessions were interspersed with presentations by speakers who were brought in to share their expertise on current, relevant work being done in WA state. The participants also learned about an NSF proposal submitted by the WA state board for community and technical colleges (SBCTC) to create a statewide resource hub for undergraduate research (the WA-CURE grant). In a post-conference survey, a vast majority of participants indicated that the conference provided the momentum they needed to introduce undergraduate research across the curriculum. Strategic plans and other ancillary materials developed at the conference were compiled within the Canvas Learning Management System (LMS) for easy reference by conference attendees. All presentations were also uploaded to Canvas for easy access.  

This conference contributed to the expansion of CUREs in nine WA state community colleges. The conference served as a springboard for future work that will be done through the WA-CURE grant (subsequently funded by NSF #2336652).
